H0.text: Age of the rocks is the basis on which rocks are classified as sedimentary, metamorphic, or igneous.

H1.text: The way the rocks were formed is the basis on which rocks are classified as sedimentary, metamorphic, or igneous.

H2.text: Types of fossils the rocks contain are the basis for classifying rocks as sedimentary, metamorphic, or igneous.

H3.text: Number of minerals found in the rocks is the basis on which rocks are classified as sedimentary, metamorphic, or igneous.

A4.text: Igneous rocks are classified based on chemical composition and mineralogy, not their age.

A5.text: Igneous rocks are classified based on chemical composition and mineralogy rather than the way they were formed.

A6.text: They are distinguished from igneous rocks, which form from molten magma, and sedimentary rocks, which form from sediments eroded from existing rock or precipitated chemically from bodies of water.

A7.text: Metamorphic rocks are formed when existing rock is transformed physically or chemically at elevated temperature, without actually melting to any great degree.
